title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this legislation. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, descendants of coastal tribes, have been recognized by the state and Congress as an Indian tribe. However, they have been denied full federal recognition and the accompanying benefits. The Lumbee Indians, descendants of coastal tribes in North Carolina, have state and Congressional recognition as an Indian tribe but lack full federal recognition and benefits. Congress acknowledges the need for the Lumbee Tribe to receive full federal recognition and the associated privileges. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive all laws and regulations applicable to Indian tribes. Non-enrolled Indians in specific counties can petition for tribal acknowledgment. Eligibility for services and benefits is also addressed. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop a determination of needs and budget in consultation with the tribe after verifying the tribal roll. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services will collaborate with the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina to determine their needs and budget for eligible services after verifying the tribal roll. This information will be included in the budget request to Congress. The tribal roll, verified by the Secretary of the Interior, will define the service population of the Tribe for the delivery of Federal services. Verification will confirm compliance with membership criteria in the Tribe's constitution within 1 year of enactment. The Tribe seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust purposes in Robeson County, North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior will treat the land as on-reservation trust acquisitions. Additionally, state jurisdiction is addressed in the following section. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the state to the United States under an agreement with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe can transfer jurisdiction from North Carolina to the United States under an agreement, with a 2-year waiting period for the transfer to take effect. This section does not impact the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorization of appropriations is granted for carrying out the Act.
